To determine the number of x-intercepts of \( y = \sin\left(\frac{1}{x}\right) \) in the interval \( (0.0001, 0.001) \), we find where \( \sin\left(\frac{1}{x}\right) = 0 \). This occurs when \( \frac{1}{x} = n\pi \) for integers \( n \), so \( x = \frac{1}{n\pi} \).

We need \( x \) in \( (0.0001, 0.001) \), which translates to:
\[
0.0001 < \frac{1}{n\pi} < 0.001
\]
Solving for \( n \):
\[
1000 < n\pi < 10000 \implies \frac{1000}{\pi} < n < \frac{10000}{\pi}
\]
Approximating:
\[
318.31 < n < 3183.098
\]
Thus, \( n \) ranges from 319 to 3183, inclusive. The number of integers in this range is:
\[
3183 - 319 + 1 = 2865
\]
